{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Decadebox|201}} The '''2010s''', pronounced "twenty-tens"<ref>{{cite web|author=Robin Lustig |authorlink=Robin Lustig |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/worldtonight/2009/12/happy_twentyten.html |title=Happy twenty-ten! |publisher=BBC |date=2009-12-31 |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> or "two thousand (and) tens",<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/2000/mill/dating.htm ]{{Dead link|date=June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/6825112/Twenty-Tens-to-become-nickname-for-next-decade-survey-says.html |title='Twenty Tens' to become nickname for next decade, survey says |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=2009-12-17 |accessdate=2010-06-21 }}</ref><ref name="guardian">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2010/jan/01/new-decade-name-2010|title= A new decade: what's in a name?|last=Jones|first=Sam|date=1 January 2010|work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=12 January 2010|location=United Kingdom}}</ref><ref name="bbcnews">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8435944.stm|title=New Year revellers welcome in 2010|date=1 January 2010|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 January 2010|location=United Kingdom}}</ref> is the current decade which began on January 1, 2010 and will end on December 31, 2019. The decade began amidst a [[Financial crisis (2007âpresent)|global financial crisis]] that started in the late 2000s, after approximately three decades of prosperity, economic growth as well as income inequality, and increased globalization.<ref>Rana Foroohar [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2088040,00.html], ''The End of Europe'', Time Magazine, 11 August 2011. Accessed 2011-08-26.</ref> In particular, the ongoing Eurozone debt crisis, which stemmed from these economic problems, first became pronounced in May 2010 and continues to threaten the possibility of a global recovery. Other economic issues such as inflation, and an increase in [[commodity]] prices, sparked immense unrest in many lower-income countries. In some countries this unrest evolved into [[socioeconomics|socio-economic]] crises which set off numerous revolutions, such as in [[Kyrgyz Revolution of 2010|Kyrgyzstan]] in 2010, and [[Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]], [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt]], and [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libya]] in 2011. This trend continues at present, and is known as the [[Arab Spring]]. The [[revolutions of 2011]] also include the [[2011 Spanish protests|Spanish "Indignants"]], inspired by the Arab Spring, and the [[Occupy movement]] protests in North America and Europe, influenced by both Spanish demonstrations and the Arab Spring.
==Mixed pronunciation== Among experts and the general public, there is some disagreement as to how specific years of the 21st century should be pronounced in English.<ref name=news.com.au>{{cite news|title=It's the end of the Noughties, we feel fine|date=26 October 2009|work=news.com.au|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,26249965-5019258,00.html|accessdate=26 October 2009 | http://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/WMFJAcontrol/en/US?utm_medium=sitenotice&utm_campaign=ControlBanner&utm_source=2010_JA1_Banner3_Control_US&country_code=USfirst=David | last=Higgins}}</ref> The year 2010, for example, was referred to by some as "twenty-ten" and by others as "two thousand (and) ten".<ref>{{cite news |last=Burnett |first=Thane |date=2009-12-28 |title=Twenty-ten, Two-oh-ten, Two thousand and ten: What is the proper way to reference 2010? |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]] |url=http://www.torontosun.com/life/columnists/thane_burnett/2009/12/24/12265106.html |accessdate=2011-01-11}}</ref> This mixed pronunciation continues in 2011.
==Politics and wars== ===Wars=== {{Main|List of wars 2003â2010|List of wars 2011âpresent}} The prominent wars of the decade so far include:
==== International wars ==== * [[War on Terrorism]] (2001âpresent) â refers to several [[Ideology|ideological]], military, and diplomatic campaigns ostensibly aimed at putting an end to [[international terrorism]] by preventing groups defined by the US and its allies as [[terrorist groups|"terrorist"]] (largely [[Islamism|Islamist]] groups such as [[al-Qaeda]], [[Hezbollah]] and [[Hamas]]) from posing a threat to the US and its allies, and by putting an end to [[state-sponsored terrorism|state sponsorship of terrorism]]. The campaigns were launched by the United States, with support from [[NATO]] and other allies, immediately following the [[11 September 2001 attacks]] which were carried out by [[al-Qaeda]]. Today the term has become mostly associated with US/UK-led wars in [[Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq]]. :*[[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)]] â In 2001, the United States, the United Kingdom, Australia and Canada invaded [[Afghanistan]] seeking to oust the [[Taliban]] and find [[Al-Qaeda]] mastermind [[Osama bin Laden]]. :* [[Iraq War]] (2003â2011) â On 19 August 2010, the last American combat brigade was moved out of Iraq after more than 7 years of warfare.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=11432471|title=Goodbye Iraq: Last US Combat Brigade Heads Home|author=Rebecca Santana|publisher=ABC}}</ref> Though about 50,000 troops remained there throughout 2011, being designated as "advise and assist brigades" assigned to non-combat operations while retaining the ability to revert to combat operations as necessary. They are expected to completely leave Iraq by the end of 2011.
* [[ArabâIsraeli conflict]] (Early 20th centuryâpresent) :*[[IsraeliâPalestinian conflict]] (Early 20th centuryâpresent) â an ongoing armed conflict in [[Israel]] and the [[Palestinian territories]]. The conflict is centered between [[the state of Israel]] and the [[Palestinian people|Palestinians]]. One side is composed mainly of [[Israeli Defence Forces|Israel's military forces]] and the other side is composed mostly of [[Palestinian political violence|Palestinian militant or paramilitary forces]] such as [[Hamas]], the [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine|Islamic Jihad Movement]], the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] and the [[Popular Resistance Committees]] (which have all been designated by the United States<ref>[http://www.state.gov/s/ct/rls/fs/37191.htm "Foreign Terrorist Organizations (FTOs)"] â U.S. Department of State</ref> and [[European Union]],<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32004E0500:EN:HTML "Council Common Position 2004/500/CFSP of 17 May 2004"] â EU list of "persons, groups and entities involved in terrorist acts"</ref> Israel and many other [[western countries]]<ref name="Japan's Diplomatic Bluebook 2005">{{cite web| url=http://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/other/bluebook/2005/ch3-a.pdf|format=PDF| title=Japan's Diplomatic Bluebook 2005|year=2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3100518.stm |title=EU blacklists Hamas political wing |publisher=BBC News |date=2003-09-11 |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> as [[terrorist organisation]]s). The conflict has escalated since the [[Second Intifada]] (September 2000) broke out, a period of intensified Palestinian-Israeli violence which has been taking place until the present day. The Second Intifada has caused thousands of victims on both sides, both among [[combatants]] and among civilians.
==== Civil wars, guerrilla wars and political revolutions ==== {{See also|Arab Spring|Impact of the Arab Spring}} [[File:Libyan flag above the communications tower in Al Bayda (Libya, 2011-07-17).jpg|thumb|250px|[[2011 Libyan uprising]]: The Libyan flag is flown from a communications tower in [[Bayda, Libya|Bayda]], July 2011]] * [[2011 Libyan Civil War]] (15 February â 23 October 2011) â a series of demonstrations and riots held against [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s [[History of Libya under Gaddafi|42-year rule]]. The widespread demonstrations, which erupted in response to the high unemployment rate in Libya and the lack of development in the country, rapidly escalated into a civil war as Gaddafi used his military force against the Libyan rebels. As a result, fifty thousand Libyans have died.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14715518 |work=BBC News | title=Libya interim leaders give ultimatum to Gaddafi forces | date=30 August 2011}}</ref> The uprising came to an end when Gaddafi was killed during the liberation of Sirte on 20 October 2011.
* [[Mexican Drug War]] (2006âpresent) â an armed conflict fought between rival [[drug cartels]] and [[Military of Mexico|government force]]s in Mexico. Although Mexican drug cartels, or drug trafficking organizations, have existed for quite some time, they have become more powerful since the demise of Colombia's [[Cali Cartel|Cali]] and [[MedellÃ­n cartel|MedellÃ­n]] cartels in the 1990s. Mexican drug cartels now dominate the wholesale [[War on Drugs|illicit drug market]] in the United States.<ref name=Cook7 >{{Citation| contribution=Mexico's Drug Cartels| title=CRS Report for Congress| editor-first=Colleen W.| editor-last=Cook| coeditors=| publisher=Congressional Research Service| place=| page=7| date=16 October| year=2007| id= | contribution-url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL34215.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-08-09 }}</ref> Arrests of key cartel leaders, particularly in the Tijuana and Gulf cartels, have led to increasing drug violence as cartels fight for control of the trafficking routes into the United States.<ref>{{cite news | first=TRACI CARL | title=Progress in Mexico drug war is drenched in blood | date=10 March 2009 | agency=Associated Press | url =http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ilIZ5du3hOOeN7yatYIRIhFY-MJAD96RBGO00 | accessdate = 2009-04-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |authorlink= | title=High U.S. cocaine cost shows drug war working: Mexico | date=14 September 2007 | publisher=Reuters | url =http://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSN1422771920070914 | accessdate = 2009-04-01 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation| contribution=CRS Report for Congress| title=Mexico â U.S. Relations: Issues for Congress| editor-first=Mark P.| editor-last=Sullivan| coeditors=Junew S. Beittel| publisher=Congressional Research Service| place=| pages=2, 13, 14| date=18 December| year=2008| id= | contribution-url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL32724.pdf| format=PDF| accessdate=2009-04-01 }}</ref> Roughly more than 28,299 people in total were killed between December 2006 until November 2010.<ref>The attorney general's office says that 9 of 10 victims are members of organized-crime groups.{{cite news | first=Sara Miller Llana | title=Briefing: How Mexico is waging war on drug cartels. | date=16 August 2009 | url =http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0819/p10s01-woam.html | work =The Christian Science Monitor | accessdate = 2009-08-20 }}</ref>
* [[War in North-West Pakistan]] (2004âpresent) â an armed conflict between the [[Pakistani Armed Forces]] and [[Islamic militants]] made up of local tribesmen, the [[Taliban]], and foreign [[Mujahideen]] (Holy Warriors). It began in 2004 when tensions rooted in the Pakistani Army's search for [[al-Qaeda]] members in [[Pakistan]]'s mountainous [[Waziristan]] area (in the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan|Federally Administered Tribal Areas]]) escalated into armed resistance by local tribesmen. The violence has displaced 3.44 million civilians<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/05/31/pakistan.red.cross/index.html |title=Red Cross 'gravely concerned' about conditions in Swat Valley |publisher=CNN |date= 2009-05-31|accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> and to more than 7,000 civilians being killed.<ref name="satp.org">{{cite web|url=http://satp.org/satporgtp/countries/pakistan/index.htm |title=SATP.org |publisher=SATP.org |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref>
* [[Sa'dah insurgency]] (2004â2010) â a civil war in the [[Sa'dah Governorate]] of [[Yemen]]. It began after the [[Shia Islam|ShÄ«âa]] [[Zaidiyyah]] sect launched an uprising against the Yemeni government. The Yemeni government has accused [[Iran]] of directing and financing the insurgency.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/terrorism/news/uploads/tf_004_002.pdf Yemen Accuses Iran of Meddling in its Internal Affairs]{{Dead link|date=June 2010}}</ref> Thousands of rebels and civilians have been killed during the conflict.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ploughshares.ca/libraries/ACRText/ACR-Yemen.htm#Status |title=Armed Conflicts Report â Yemen |publisher=Ploughshares.ca |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/World/Yemeni-military-battles-Shiite-rebels/2007/03/20/1174153010354.html |title=Yemeni military battles Shi'ite rebels |work=The Age |location=Australia |date=2007-03-20 |accessdate=2010-06-21 | location=Melbourne}}</ref>
* [[War in Somalia (2009â)|War in Somalia (2009âpresent)]] â involved largely the forces of the Somali [[Somalia|Somali]] [[Transitional Federal Parliament|Transitional Federal Government]] (TFG) assisted by [[African Union]] peacekeeping troops, whom fought against various militant Islamist factions for control of the country. The violence has displaced thousands of people residing in [[Mogadishu]], the nation's capital. 1,739 people in total were killed between 1 January 2009 until 1 January 2010.<ref name=casualties>[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/201001010001.html More Than 1,700 Killed in Clashes in 2009], 1 January 2010</ref>
* [[Conflict in the Niger Delta]] (2004âpresent) â an ongoing conflict in the [[Niger Delta]] region of [[Nigeria]]. The conflict was caused due to the tensions between the [[multinational corporation|foreign]] [[oil industry|oil corporations]] and a number of the [[Niger Delta]]'s minority ethnic groups who felt they were being exploited, particularly the [[Ogoni people|Ogoni]] and the [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]]. The competition for oil wealth has led to an endless violence cycle between innumerable [[ethnic groups]], causing the [[militarization]] of nearly the entire region which was occupied by militia groups as well as [[Military of Nigeria|Nigerian military]] and the forces of the Nigerian Police.
* [[Civil war in Chad (2005âpresent)]] involved [[Chad]]ian government forces and several Chadian rebel groups. The government of Chad estimated in January 2006 that 614 Chadian citizens had been killed in cross-border raids.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Chad wants Sudan to disarm rebels|date=2006-01-12|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/English/archive/archive?ArchiveId=17880}}</ref> The fighting still continues despite several attempts to reach agreements.
* [[Insurgency in the Maghreb (2002âpresent)]] â [[Algeria]] has been the subject of an Islamic insurgency since 2002 waged by the Sunni Islamic [[Jihad]]ist militant group [[Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat]] (GSPC). GSPC allied itself with the [[Al-Qaeda Organization in the Islamic Maghreb]] against the [[Algeria|Algerian government]]. The conflict has since spread to other neighboring countries.
* [[Colombian Armed Conflict]] (1964âpresent) has changed substantially after the government of [[Alvaro Uribe]]. President [[Juan Manuel Santos]] took office in 2010 and seeks to continue Uribe's policy about terrorism. The [[FARC]] and [[ELN]] guerrillas are weaker than ever and divided, with the latter calling for peace talks with the government. Meanwhile, paramilitary forces have demobilized, but irregular drug-trafficking forces called "Bacrim" have gained control over much of the areas that the [[United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia|AUC]] paramilitaries previously held. The "Bacrim" gangs have allied with guerrillas in some regions of the country like [[ChocÃ³]] and [[Antioquia]].
=== Coups === {{Main|List of coups d'Ã©tat and coup attempts#2010 - present}}
=== Terrorist attacks === {{Main|List of terrorist incidents#1970âpresent}} The most prominent [[terror attack|terrorist attacks]] committed against civilian population during the decade include: * [[2010 Moscow Metro bombings]] (40 killed) * [[10 May 2010 Iraq attacks]] (100+ killed) * [[May 2010 attacks on Ahmadi mosques in Lahore]] (86 killed) * [[Mohmand Agency attack]] (105 killed) * [[September 2010 Quetta bombing]] (73+ killed) * [[2011 Domodedovo International Airport bombing]] (at least 35 people killed and 180 injured) * [[2011 Norway attacks]] (two separate attacks; 77 deaths) * [[2011 Monterrey casino attack]] (52 killed)
===Nuclear weapons controversies=== * Since 2005, [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran's nuclear program]] has become the subject of contention with the Western world due to suspicions that Iran could divert the civilian nuclear technology to a weapons program. This has led the [[UN Security Council]] to impose [[sanctions against Iran]] on select companies linked to this program, thus furthering its economic isolation on the international scene. The [[U.S. Director of National Intelligence]] said in February 2009 that Iran would not realistically be able to a get a nuclear weapon until 2013, if it chose to develop one.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN25158068 |title=RPT-EXCLUSIVE-Iran would need 18 months for atom bomb-diplomats |publisher=Reuters |date= 2009-10-26|accessdate=2010-06-21 | first=Louis | last=Charbonneau}}</ref>
* The United States and Russia sign a treaty to cut nuclear weapons in either nation in Prague in April 2010, a week later U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] hosts a [[2010 Nuclear Security Summit|Nuclear Security Summit]] where the attending nations decides to lock onto their nuclear arms, to make sure no terrorists get hands on these weapons of mass destruction, also South Korea was selected to hold the second [[2012 Nuclear Security Summit|Nuclear Security Summit]] in 2012.
=== Political events === The prominent political events of the decade so far include:
'''WikiLeaks''' * The international new-media non-profit organization [[WikiLeaks]] published three massive sets of documents pertaining to the [[Iraq War]], the [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|Afghanistan War]], and [[United States diplomatic cables leak|US diplomacy]], which, respectively, were released in April, July, and November 2010. Each of these releases was accompanied by heavy and extensive weeks-long coverage in news media all over the world, and had a strong impact on the global political landscape, with strong reactions from leaders within many major countries.
'''Americas''' [[File:Obama and Medvedev sign Prague Treaty 2010.jpeg|thumb|Obama signing the [[New START]] treaty in Prague.]] * January 2010 â A trial determining the [[constitutionality]] of [[same-sex marriage in the United States]] is held in California.<ref>[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100127/ap_on_re_us/us_gay_marriage_trial_15 California gay marriage trial moves to a close]{{Dead link|date=June 2010}}</ref> * The [[Obama administration]]'s efforts to implement [[health care reform in the United States]] lead eventually to the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] voting in favor of enacting the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] in March 2010. Republicans are currently making efforts to repeal the bill, debating its [[constitutionality]]. * The late 2000s and early 2010s has seen the rise of the [[Tea Party movement]], with figureheads like [[Glenn Beck]] and [[Sarah Palin]], which has acquired a large following in the United States. The movement has become a dominant factor in the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and has provided a strong political polarization, promoting activism and [[Tea Party protests|protests]] with the goal to reduce federal spending, bailouts, taxes, and regulation. * The [[New START]], a nuclear arms reduction treaty between the United States and the [[Russian Federation]] entered into force.
'''Europe''' <!-- I propose we wait till this is expanded to add a pic, because it looks stupid, with a picture larger than the sub-topic itself. --> * The [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 United Kingdom election]] resulted in the first "[[hung parliament]]" since [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974|1974]]. [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]], under Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] lost its overall majority in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]]. The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]] led by [[David Cameron]] became the largest party. For five days, both major parties held negotiations with the [[Nick Clegg]]'s [[Liberal Democrats]], resulting in the first peace-time [[coalition government]] since the [[Fourth National Ministry|1930s]]. leading to talks for over a week between the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and the [[Liberal Democrats]]. Cameron became Prime Minister upon Brown's resignation on 11 May. Clegg also became [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]]. * The [[Scottish National Party]] win an overall majority in the [[Scottish Parliament]] at the [[Scottish Parliament general election, 2011|2011 Scottish Parliament election]] under Scotland's [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Alex Salmond]]. The SNP's transition from a minority government to a majority government has allowed them to pledge to have a referendum on Scottish Independence from the United Kingdom. *Italian Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] is indicted for [[Rubygate|allegedly paying for sex with an underage nightclub dancer]], and ordered to stand trial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/15/silvio-berlusconi-trial-teenage-sex|title=Silvio Berlusconi sent for trial accused of paying for sex with teenager|first=John|last=Hooper|date=15 February 2011|work=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref>
'''Africa''' [[File:Tahrir Square during 8 February 2011.jpg|thumb|[[2011 Egyptian revolution]]: Demonstrators in Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] on 8 February 2011]] * Between 9â15 January 2011 a [[Southern Sudanese independence referendum, 2011|referendum]] was held in [[Southern Sudan]] on whether the region should remain a part of Sudan or become independent. In the referendum a majority of 98.83% voted in favour of separation from Sudan and the creation of an independent state. * 14 January 2011 â Amidst [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|anti-government demonstrations]], Tunisia's President [[Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali]] dissolves the government, declares a state of emergency, and resigns from office. * JanuaryâFebruary 2011 â Inspired by the Tunisian demonstrators, thousands of [[2011 Egyptian protests|protesters]] in Egypt call for a resignation or ousting of [[Hosni Mubarak]], longtime president of the nation, who many feel has been in power far too long and has no interests of the public. Mubarak resigns on 11 February. * FebruaryâOctober: a [[2011 Libyan uprising|popular revolt]] against [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s 42-year rule over Libya leads to thousands of deaths and [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1970|UN sanctions]] against the nation's government following a brutal crackdown against protestors.<ref name=un>{{cite news|url=http://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2011/sc10187.doc.htm|title=In swift, decisive action, Security Council imposes tough measures on Libyan regime, adopting Resolution 1970 in wake of crackdown on protesters|date=26 February 2011|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=2011-03-04}}</ref>
'''Oceania''' *June 2010 â [[Julia Gillard]] succeeds [[Kevin Rudd]] as the [[Prime Minister of Australia]], thus becoming Australia's 27th and first female [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]].
==Assassinations, targeted killings, and assassination attempts== {{Main|List of assassinations and assassination attempts}} {{multiple image | direction = horizontal | width = | footer = | image1 = Osama bin Laden portrait2.jpg | alt1 = | width1 = 128 | caption1 =[[Osama bin Laden]] | caption2 =[[Muammar Gaddafi]] | image2 = Muammar al-Gaddafi 1-1.jpg | alt2 = | width2 = 120 | caption2 =[[Muammar Gaddafi]] }} Prominent assassinations, targeted killings, and assassination attempts of the decade so far include: * 8 January 2011 â [[Gabrielle Giffords]], U.S. Representative from Arizona, was a victim of a [[2011 Tucson shooting|shooting near Tucson]] which was reported to be an assassination attempt on her, at a supermarket where she was meeting publicly with constituents. Giffords was critically injured by a gunshot wound to the head; 13 people were injured and 6 others were killed in the shooting, among them conservative federal judge [[John Roll]]. * 2 May 2011 â [[Osama bin Laden]], the founder and leader of the militant Islamist group [[Al-Qaeda]], was [[Death of Osama bin Laden|killed]] in a [[targeted killing]] in [[Abbottabad]], Pakistan in an operation conducted by a team of [[United States Navy SEAL]] [[commando]]s from the [[United States Naval Special Warfare Development Group|Naval Special Warfare Development Group]] (DEVGRU), under the command of the [[Joint Special Operations Command]], in conjunction with U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA) operatives. * 30 September 2011 â [[Anwar al-Awlaki]], a senior talent recruiter, planner, and spiritual leader of al-Qaeda, was killed in a [[targeted killing]] in the northern [[Al Jawf Governorate|al-Jawf]] province of Yemen, in an operation carried out by the US military in which two [[Predator drone]]s fired [[Hellfire missiles]] at a vehicle in which he and other suspected al-Qaeda members were driving, killing them.<ref name="foxnews1">{{cite news|last=Griffin |first=Jennifer |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/09/30/us-born-terror-boss-anwar-al-awlaki-killed/ |title=Two U.S.-Born Terrorists Killed in CIA-Led Drone Strike |publisher=Fox News |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=30 September 2011}}</ref> The strike was carried out by Joint Special Operations Command, under the direction of the CIA.<ref name="foxnews1"/> * 21 October 2011 â [[Muammar Gaddafi]], Libya's ousted leader, was [[Death of Muammar Gaddafi|shot to death]] in [[Sirte]], with National Transitional Council forces [[Battle of Sirte (2011)|taking control of the city]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Rana Jawad |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15389550 |title=BBC News â Libya's Col Muammar Gaddafi killed, says NTC |publisher=BBC |date=20 October 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
==Disasters== The most prominent [[disasters]] of the decade so far include:
=== Non-natural disasters === ====Aviation disasters==== [[File:2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash 002.jpg|180px|thumb|right|The wreckage site of the [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|Polish Air Force Tu-154]] near [[Smolensk]]]] * On 25 January 2010, [[Ethiopian Airlines Flight 409]] crashes into the [[Mediterranean Sea]] shortly after take-off from [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]], killing all 90 people on board. * On 10 April 2010, Polish President [[Lech KaczyÅski]], his wife, and 94 other people, including dozens of government officials, are killed in [[2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash|a plane crash]]. * On 12 May 2010 [[Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771]] crashes on a runway at [[Tripoli International Airport]] in Libya, killing 103 of 104 on board.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8676898.stm |work=BBC News | title=Briton among Libya air crash dead | date=2010-05-13}}</ref> * On 22 May 2010 [[Air India Express Flight 812]] overshoots the runway at [[Mangalore International Airport]] in India, killing 158 and leaving 8 survivors.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/AS_INDIA_PLANE_CRASH?SITE=NYMID&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title=Plane crashes in India, 158 feared dead, 8 alive |accessdate=2010-05-22 |agency=Associated Press |date=2010-05-22}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> * On 28 July 2010 a Pakistan [[Airblue Flight 202]] en route from [[Karachi]] to [[Islamabad]] crashes in the [[Margalla Hills]] near Islamabad, killing all 152 aboard. * On 26 July 2011 a [[2011 Royal Moroccan Air Force Lockheed C-130 Hercules crash|Royal Moroccan Air Force Lockheed C-130 Hercules]] crashed into Sayyert Mountain while en route to Kenitra Air Base from [[Dakhla Airport]] with a scheduled stop-over in Guelmim, killing all 80 on board. {{-}}
====Pollution disasters==== [[File:Deepwater Horizon oil spill - May 24, 2010.jpg|thumb|right|180px|The [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]] as seen from space by [[NASA]]'s [[Terra (satellite)|Terra]] satellite on 24 May 2010]] * On 20 April 2010, an explosion on [[BP]]'s ''[[Deepwater Horizon]]'' offshore [[drilling rig]], operating in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] off the coast of [[Louisiana]], left eleven crewmen dead and resulted in a fire that sank the rig and caused a massive-scale [[oil spill]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126468782|title=BP Will Pay For Gulf Oil Spill Disaster, CEO Says|publisher = NPR|date=2010-05-03 |accessdate=2010-05-03}}</ref> that became [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|the worst environmental disaster in United States history]].<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite news | url = http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE65F02C20100616 | title = Full text of President Obama's BP Oil Spill speech |agency=Reuters | date = 2010-06-15 | accessdate = 2010-06-16}}</ref> On 18 June 2010, oceanographer John Kessler said that the crude gushing from the well contains 40 percent methane, compared to about 5 percent found in typical oil deposits. Methane is a natural gas that could potentially suffocate marine life and create "dead zones" where oxygen is so depleted that nothing lives. "This is the most vigorous methane eruption in modern human history," Kessler said.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/37778190/ns/disaster_in_the_gulf/ |title=Oil spill full of methane, adding new concerns |publisher =msnbc |date=2010-06-18 |accessdate = 2010-06-20}}</ref> On 20 June an internal BP document was released by Congress revealing that BP estimated the flow could be as much as {{convert|100000|oilbbl|USgal m3|abbr=off}} per day under the circumstances that existed since the 20 April blowout.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=10964694 |title=Document Shows BP Estimates Spill up to 100,000 Bpd |publisher =ABC News |date=2010-06-20 |accessdate = 2010-06-20}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://globalwarming.house.gov/files/WEB/flowrateBP.pdf |accessdate = 2010-06-20}}</ref> On 15 July 2010, The BP Oil Spill was stopped for the first time, 86 days after oil started leaking into the Gulf of Mexico.
* On 11 March 2011, a magnitude 9.0<ref name="USGS9.0">{{cite web|url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqinthenews/2011/usc0001xgp/ |title= Magnitude 9.0 â Near The East Coast Of Honshu, Japan|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS) |accessdate=13 March 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5xgj6FuHC|archivedate=5 April 2011}}</ref> [[2011 TÅhoku earthquake and tsunami|earthquake off the coast of Sendai]] caused a tsunami that severely damaged the [[Fukushima Daiichi]] and [[Fukushima Daini]] nuclear power plants. The damage resulted in the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|worst nuclear disaster since the Chernobyl disaster]], contaminating water, soil and crops in the area with [[Iodine-131]] and [[Caesium-137]]. {{-}}
=== Natural disasters === [[File:Downtown Port au Prince after earthquake.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Damage in downtown [[Port-au-Prince]], 13 January 2010]] [[File:Chile-earthquacke.jpg|180px|right|thumb|Chileans look at tsunami-provoked damage in the city of [[Pichilemu]], following the [[2010 Chile earthquake]].]] [[File:SH-60B helicopter flies over Sendai.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[2011 TÅhoku earthquake and tsunami]]: An aerial view of tsunami damage in TÅhoku]] [[Image:Irene ISS028-E-031903 Aug 24 2011.jpg|thumb|right|The eye of Irene as viewed from the [[International Space Station]]]] * On 12 January 2010 a [[2010 Haiti earthquake|7.0 magnitude earthquake]] hits [[Haiti]], causing widespread destruction in [[Port-au-Prince]]. Haitian authorities currently believe that the disaster killed between 200,000 and 250,000 people.<ref name='reutersfirst'>{{cite news | first=Jane | last=Sutton | coauthors= Anthony Boadle, Pascal Fletcher | title=Haiti quake death toll may hit 200,000-minister | date=15 January 2010 | publisher=Reuters | url =http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N15143632.htm | work =Reuters Alertnet| accessdate = 15 January 2010 }}</ref> Over 2 million people were affected and over 3 million in need of emergency aid. * On 27 February 2010 an [[2010 Chile earthquake|8.8 magnitude earthquake]] occurs in [[Chile]], triggering a [[tsunami]] over the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] and killing 497.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cooperativa.cl/gobierno-entrego-lista-de-497-fallecidos-en-el-terremoto/prontus_nots/2010-03-08/135659.html |title=Gobierno entregÃ³ lista de 497 fallecidos en el terremoto |publisher=Cooperativa.cl |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> One of the [[largest earthquakes]] in recorded history, this rare [[megathrust earthquake]] probably shifts Earth's [[Axial tilt|axis]] and slightly shortens its days.<ref name = "Newitz">[[Annalee Newitz|Newitz A]] (2010). [http://io9.com/5485130/why-the-chile-earthquake-deformed-the-earth-and-shortened-our-days "Why the Chile earthquake deformed the earth and shortened our days"]. ''[[io9]]''. Retrieved 20 March 2010.</ref><ref name = "Than">Than K (2010, 2 March). [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/03/100302-chile-earthquake-earth-axis-shortened-day/ "Chile earthquake altered Earth axis, shortened day"]. ''[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic News]]''. Retrieved 20 March 2010.</ref> [[2010 Pichilemu earthquake|Another earthquake]], of magnitude 6.9, occurred on 11 March of the same year, minutes before President [[SebastiÃ¡n PiÃ±era]] was sworn in; it was centered in [[Pichilemu]], [[Cardenal Caro Province]].<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1119348920100311 |title=Billionaire Pinera takes power as quakes jolt Chile |publisher=Reuters |author=Javier LÃ³pez |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=5 September 2010}}</ref> * In early 2010, [[2010 eruptions of EyjafjallajÃ¶kull|eruptions of the EyjafjallajÃ¶kull volcano]] caused unprecedented [[Air travel disruption after the 2010 EyjafjallajÃ¶kull eruption|disruption to international air travel]], rendering transatlantic flight impossible and closing the airways over much of Europe. * On 4 April 2010 ([[Easter Sunday]]) a [[2010 Baja California earthquake|7.2 magnitude earthquake]] hit [[Mexicali]], [[Baja California]], Mexico killing four and injuring a hundred. The neighboring United States border towns in [[Imperial Valley]], California were also affected. * On 14 April 2010 a [[2010 Yushu earthquake|6.9 magnitude earthquake]] occurs in western [[People's Republic of China|China]], killing at least 2,200 and injuring more than 12,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/China-Earthquake-400-Killed-In-Qinghai-Provinces-Yushu-Region-After-69-Magnitude-Tremor/Article/201004215601424?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_3&lid=ARTICLE_15601424_China_Earthquake%3A_400_Killed_In_Qinghai_Provinces_Yushu_Region_After_6.9_Magnitude_Tremor |title=China Earthquake: 589 Killed In Qinghai Province's Yushu Region After 6.9 Magnitude Tremor | World News | Sky News |publisher=News.sky.com |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8619593.stm | work=BBC News | title=Hundreds die in west China quake | date=2010-04-14 | accessdate=2010-04-23}}</ref> * Early November 2010 â [[2010 eruptions of Mount Merapi|Mount Merapi erupts in Indonesia]], killing hundreds and grounding flights to [[Singapore]], [[Jakarta]] and other [[Southeast Asian]] cities. * [[2010 Pakistan floods]] â Began in July 2010 after record heavy [[monsoon]] rains. The [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] province of [[Pakistan]] was worst affected. At least 1,600 people were killed, thousands were rendered homeless, and more than thirteen million people were affected.<ref name="Bodeen">{{cite news|last=Bodeen|first=Christopher|title=Asia flooding plunges millions into misery|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jLQ5AssQ1MzPfWcFQRV8ZeJhjctQD9HFBA400|accessdate=8 August 2010|newspaper=The Associated Press|date=8 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="nyt">Masood, Salman and Adam B. Ellick. [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/02/world/asia/02pstan.html Floods in Pakistan Kill at Least 700]. NYTimes. <!--On Sunday officials reduced the number of dead to 730, saying earlier reports on Sunday, reaching as high at 1,100, were not credible.--></ref><ref name="bbc20100731">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-10827712|title=UN voices Pakistan flood fears as death toll soars|date={{Nowrap|31 July}} 2010|publisher=BBC |accessdate={{Nowrap|31 July}} 2010}}</ref><ref name="nyt20100730">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/31/world/asia/31pstan.html|title=400 Killed in Flooding in Pakistan, Officials Say|last=Khan|first=Ismail|work=The New York Times|accessdate={{Nowrap|30 July}} 2010 | date=2010-07-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100801/ap_on_re_as/as_pakistan_floods|title=Thousands trapped by Pakistan floods; 900 dead|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref> Estimates from rescue service officials suggest the death toll may reach 3,000 victims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-31/pakistan-death-toll-from-flash-floods-in-northwest-rises-to-539-edhi-says.html|title=Deaths From Pakistan Floods May Reach 3,000, Rescue Service Official Says|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> * On 11 and 12 January 2011, occurred Brazil's worst natural disaster ever. The [[January 2011 Rio de Janeiro floods and mudslides]] killed more than 900 people in 7 cities os the state of [[Rio de Janeiro]] and left demages that costed more than US$ 1.2 billion dollars. * On 22 February 2011, a [[February 2011 Christchurch earthquake|6.3 magnitude earthquake]] hit [[Christchurch]], New Zealand, killing 181 and leaving 200 more missing. * On 11 March 2011, a [[2011 TÅhoku earthquake and tsunami|9.0 magnitude earthquake]] hit near [[Sendai]], Japan, creating a 10 meter (33 foot) tsunami, leaving over 15,000 now confirmed dead, possibly over 10,000 missing and over 150,000 people displaced into emergency shelters.<ref>Wikinews."Crisis at stricken Japan nuclear plant escalates to level of Chernobyl; six killed in aftershock".[[n:Crisis at stricken Japan nuclear plant escalates to level of Chernobyl; six killed in aftershock]], "Wikinews", 12 April 2011, accessed 13 April 2011</ref> The earthquake and tsunami also damaged several nuclear reactors in the region, leaving at least one [[Fukushima I nuclear accidents|in danger of melting down]]. This was recorded as the worst earthquake in Japan. Damages could exceed over $300 billion, making it the costliest natural disaster. * The [[2011 Super Outbreak]] happened from 25â28 April 2011, killing 340+ people, injuring thousands and caused $10 billion of damage from the 332 confirmed tornadoes. 27 April was the worst tornado day since the "Tri-State" outbreak in 1925. It is now the deadliest tornado outbreak in the history of the United States of America. Before the disaster occurred, merely two weeks prior, the states affected in the outbreak had also been damaged from the [[14â16 April 2011 tornado outbreak]], leaving 43 people dead. * The [[21â27 May 2011 tornado outbreak]] was over a span of seven days in which 183 people were confirmed dead from 180 confirmed tornadoes. After a record active April, May was relatively quiet during the first three weeks until that pattern changed abruptly as a strong low pressure area and associated dry line and cold front tracked eastward towards the [[Midwest]] of the United States in late May. More than a third of the deaths is contributed from the EF5 [[2011 Joplin tornado]] on 22 May, which killed 159, injured 900+ and ranks as the seventh-deadliest single tornado in US history. Damages for the whole outbreak is between $4â7 billion. * [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] wreaks havoc across the [[Caribbean]], then makes several landfalls as a major [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3]] in the [[Bahamas]] and threatened over 65 million people in the [[United States East Coast|US East Coast]] during late August. Irene made three US landfalls in the states of [[North Carolina]], [[New Jersey]] and New York over a two-day span. Overall, 55 fatalities and over $10.1 billion in damages were contributed. * The [[2011 Van earthquake]] strikes the Turkish city of Van, leaving over 610 dead and thousands injured. * A rare October [[2011 Halloween nor'easter|snow storm]] hits the [[Northeastern United States (U.S. Census Bureau)|northeastern United States]] and [[mid-Atlantic United States|Mid-Atlantic]] United States, leaving millions without power, killing 15. * The [[2011 Bering Sea superstorm]] is currently active.
== Economics ==
The [[Late-2000s recession|Great Recession]], which began in the year 2007, officially ended in mid-2009, though unemployment has failed to recover. In the United States, a [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll found that more than half of Americans believe the country is still in a recession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/147299/half-say-recession-depression.aspx |title=More Than Half Still Say U.S. Is in Recession or Depression |publisher=Gallup.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Some economists believe that the 'recession' has not only not ended, but is actually an [[economic depression]] much like the one in the [[1930s]]. <ref>http://www.cnbc.com/id/38831550/Economy_Caught_in_Depression_Not_Recession_Rosenberg</ref> There is an [[2008 energy crisis|energy crisis]] in the world, partially due to the protests and riots in the Middle East and North Africa, though prices had been rising beforehand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/01/gas-prices-rising-2011_n_803151.html |title=$4 Gasoline In 2011: Oil's Surge Paves Way For Higher Prices At The Pump |work=Huffington Post |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Production of conventional crude oil peaked in 2004 at 74 million barrels per day, and greater records reached since then represent only small increases that are failing to keep pace with demand from growing countries, such as China and India.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/post/defining-peak-oil/2011/10/06/gIQABuLgQL_blog.html | work=Washington Post | title=Why is it so tricky to define âpeak oilâ? | date=2011-10-06 | accessdate=4 November 2011 | first1=Brad | last1=Plumer}}</ref> This is evident because of the relatively small output that was shut off during the Libya civil war, as well as the failure of releases from strategic reserves to stem high prices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Update-on-Libyan-Oil-Production.html |title=Update on Libyan Oil Production at Oil Price |publisher=Oilprice.com |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/06/30/markets/oil_prices/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Oil prices rising a week after SPR release | date=30 June 2011}}</ref> The [[International Energy Agency]] has found that global crude oil production reached its apex in 2006, meaning production from currently producing oil fields is forecast to drop and future oil supply projections are uncertain.<ref>{{cite web|last=Morran |first=Chris |url=http://consumerist.com/2011/08/shoppers-hoarding-incandescent-light-bulbs.html |title=Shoppers Hoarding Incandescent Light Bulbs As New Regulations Loom |publisher=The Consumerist |date=8 August 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2010-04-23-louisiana-oil-rig-explosion_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Oil drilling accidents prompting new safety rules | date=24 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/14/is-peak-oil-behind-us/ | work=NY Times | title=Is Peak Oil Behind Us? | date=2010-11-14 | accessdate=2011-08-23}}</ref> Another school of opinion attributes the high energy prices in the western world to government regulation.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blog.heritage.org/2011/07/22/new-study-forecasts-huge-job-growth-if-regulators-allow-gulf-oil-drilling/ |work=BBC News | title=New Study Forecasts Huge Job Growth If Regulators Allow Gulf Oil Drilling | date=2011-07-22 | accessdate=2011-08-23}}</ref>
A [[European sovereign debt crisis of 2010âpresent|sovereign debt crisis]] in Europe began in early 2010, and the Greek government admitted that it was having difficulties servicing its large [[sovereign debt]]. Speculation abounded that it would be unable to make required [[Government bond|bond]] payments due in 2010. causing the Euro to drop in value versus the US dollar and pushing the Greek/German [[yield spread]] to almost 4%. In May 2010, Eurozone leaders agreed to a Â£110 billion euro three year rescue package.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8656649.stm |work=BBC News | title=Huge Greece bail-out deal agreed | date=2 May 2010}}</ref> However, by the following year, the country's fiscal condition had not improved.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/international/greece_in_second_bailout_talks_XSek5vYAKN6Q2DmTiJ871L | work=New York Post | title=Greece in second bailout talks | date=19 June 2011}}</ref> In July 2011 [[Standard & Poor's]] announced that the second bailout package for [[Greece]] will be defined as a partial default.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2011/08/21/bloomberg1376-LQBENZ6TTDS001-7N1TOHKOQJ6OHGFLBMFS4REACP.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=S&P's Beers Says Greece to Default on Debt by End of This Year | date=21 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Willis |first=Bob |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-27/greece-will-partially-default-on-debt-after-eu-plan-takes-place-s-p-says.html |title=Greece Will Default on Debt After EU Plan: S&P |publisher=Bloomberg |date=27 July 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> In the midst of this bond yields for [[Italy]] and Spain spike above 6 percent.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-14385636 |work=BBC News | title=Bond market developments are deep concern, says Barroso | date=3 August 2011}}</ref> China becomes the second largest global economy, surpassing Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110214/ap_on_bi_ge/as_japan_economy|title=Japan confirms China surpassed its economy in 2010|author=Tomoko A. Hosaka|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref> China currently faces out-of-control inflation, a real estate bubble, and troubling demographics that will lead to a shrinking labor force, all of which could lead to a collapse of the Chinese economy.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lawrence Delevingne | 22 Jan. 2010, 9:07 am | 458,387 | 85 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/stratfor-predictions-for-the-next-decade-2010-1#china-doomed-1 |title=STRATFOR'S TOP PREDICTIONS FOR THE NEXT DECADE: China Collapse, Global Labor Shortages, New American Dominance |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=22 January 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>http://opinion.financialpost.com/2011/01/27/lawrence-solomon-chinaâs-coming-collapse/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/175179/20110706/china-economic-bubble-housing-bubble-job-growth-asia-bubble-china-interest-rates-recession-inflation.htm |title=5 Reasons China's Bubble Will Burst â International Business Times |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date=6 July 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
Debt struggles plague advanced countries. The crisis in Greece fuels growing fears of contagion.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://business.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/17/fears-of-lehman-like-greece-contagion/ | work=CNN | title=Fears of 'Lehman-like' Greek contagion}}</ref> Beyond Greece, European countries such as Ireland, Italy, Spain and [[Portugal]] see their credit rating downgraded.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/business/treasury-prices-rise-after-fitch-downgrades-credit-ratings-of-spain-and-italy/2011/10/07/gIQAAgJKTL_story.html | work=Washington Post | title=Treasury prices rise after Fitch downgrades credit ratings of Spain and Italy | date=7 Oct. 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/06/us-eurozone-idUSTRE7651EK20110706 | work=Reuters | title=EU slams ratings agencies after Portugal downgraded | date=6 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/8452896/Moodys-downgrades-Irelands-debt-cites-weaker-growth.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Moody's downgrades Ireland's debt, cites weaker growth | date=15 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2011/oct/04/italy-downgrade-moodys-debt-crisis |work=The Guardian |location=UK | title=Italy downgrade deepens contagion fears over euro debt crisis | date=2011-10-04 | accessdate=2011-10-04 | first1=Dominic | last1=Rushe}}</ref> In August 2011, the S&P downgrades the United States' [[credit rating]] from triple AAA to AA-plus.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/06/us-usa-debt-downgrade-idUSTRE7746VF20110806 | work=Reuters | title=United States loses prized AAA credit rating from S&P | date=6 August 2011}}</ref> In September 2011 Italy is downgraded by S&P from A+.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/8775575/SandP-downgrades-Italy-as-Greek-austerity-row-forces-global-stock-markets-lower.html | work=The Telegraph| title=S&P downgrades Italy as Greek austerity row forces global stock markets lower | date=2011-09-19 | accessdate=19 September 2011}}</ref> Japan also sees a rating downgrade due to debt burden.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fujioka |first=Toru |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-23/moody-s-lowers-japan-s-government-credit-rating-to-aa3-outlook-stable.html |title=Japan Unveils $100 Billion to Fight Surging Yen as Moodyâs Lowers Rating |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> In October 2011 European leaders devised another Greek debt agreement in which private banks that loaned Greece money agreed to voluntarily write down or revalue Greek debt by 50%. The size of the [[EFSF]] was increased from â¬440 billion to â¬1 trillion.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/27/business/euro-debt-crisis-plan/index.html?iref=obnetwork| work=CNN | title=Does debt deal solve euro woes? | date=27 October 2011}}</ref> From 2010 to 2011 gold prices rise from $1121.50 an ounce to $1,917.90.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usagold.com/reference/prices/2010.html |title=Gold Price History â 2010 â London Gold Fixing |publisher=Usagold.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sim |first=Glenys |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-08-23/gold-tops-1-900-for-first-time-on-concern-global-economy-may-weaken-more.html |title=Gold Tops $1,910 for First Time |publisher=Bloomberg |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
== Society ==
The 2010s are notable for being the first decade in which the population of Earth has been more [[urban]] than [[rural]]; back in 2007, the portion of the human population living in cities and urban areas reached the 50% mark. <ref>http://www.gizmag.com/go/7334/</ref>
The world population is projected to peak at 9 billion by 2050, and many countries reported declining fertility rates in the 2010 census.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalpublicsquare.blogs.cnn.com/2011/10/31/the-end-of-population-growth/ |title=The end of population growth â Global Public Square â CNN.com Blogs |publisher=Globalpublicsquare.blogs.cnn.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Society by the 2010's is still being accustomed to the huge changes the Internet, [[globalization]] and [[digital technology]] make in everyday life, with many young people growing up spending their entire lives exposed to [[microchip]] technology.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/06/10/business/main6568258.shtml | work=CBS News | title=Generation X (and Y) Are History; What's Next?}}</ref> At the same time, the world is grappling with the [[Late-2000s recession|Great Recession]] that began in 2007 and continues into the '10s.
Environmentalism continues to become mainstream, but not as mainstream as it was in the 1990's and 2000's {{citation needed|date=November 2011}} {{dubious|date=November 2011}}, and with the economic crisis of the late '00s to present, increasingly profitable as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reddit.com/r/energy/comments/e82eo/recession_it_turns_out_is_good_for_fuel_economy/ |title=Recession, it turns out, is good for fuel economy. Gas mileage for 2009 model cars and trucks showed the largest increase since the oil crisis of nearly three decades ago, according to an annual report by the Environmental Protection Agency : energy |publisher=Reddit.com |date=18 November 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
In the United States, liberal economic policies decline in popularity, and the public supports more conservative economic policies. {{dubious|date=November 2011}} <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/general_politics/august_2011/11_think_government_should_provide_basic_income_grant_for_all |title=11% Think Government Should Provide Basic Income Grant for All â Rasmussen Reportsâ¢ |publisher=Rasmussenreports.com |date=1 September 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/1645/Guns.aspx |title=Guns |publisher=Gallup.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/obama_and_democrats_health_care_plan-1130.html |title=Election Other â Obama and Democrats' Health Care Plan |publisher=RealClearPolitics |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/13/AR2009031301899.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Billy | last=Wharton | title=Obama's No Socialist. I Should Know | date=15 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2011/06/08/cnn-poll-obama-approval-rating-drops-as-fears-of-depression-rise/ | work=CNN | title=CNN Poll: Obama approval rating drops as fears of depression rise}}</ref><ref>http://i2.cdn.turner.com/cnn/2010/images/08/13/rel11d.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Quinnipiac University â Office of Public Affairs |url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/x1295.xml?ReleaseID=1478 |title=National (US) Poll * July 21, 2010 * Obama Approval Drops To Lowest â Quinnipiac University â Hamden, Connecticut |publisher=Quinnipiac.edu |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> Political polarization grows as conservatives and progressives clash over the role of government. Polls continue to show a divided electorate regarding job creation, debt reduction, and taxation.<ref name="rasmussenreports.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/mood_of_america/generic_congressional_ballot |title=Generic Congressional Ballot â Rasmussen Reportsâ¢ |publisher=Rasmussenreports.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/index.html?story=/politics/war_room/2011/09/04/favoritesonsanddaughters ]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|author=Zeke Miller | 10 Aug. 2011, 9:00 am | 3,260 | 42 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/americans-want-higher-taxes-on-wealthy-no-entitlement-reform-in-super-committee-deal-2011-8 |title=Americans Want Higher Taxes On Wealthy, No Entitlement Reform In 'Super Committee' Deal |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=10 August 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Posted on 5 September 2011 |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2011/09/05/herman_cain_obama_just_doesnt_have_a_clue_on_economic_issues.html |title=Herman Cain: Obama "Just Doesn't Have A Clue" On Economic Issues |publisher=RealClearPolitics |date=5 September 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.democracycorps.com/wp-content/files/dcor120811fq_WEBSITE.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/mood_of_america/congressional_favorability_ratings |title=Congressional Favorability Ratings â Rasmussen Reportsâ¢ |publisher=Rasmussenreports.com |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
Acceptance of GLBT people slowly increases across the world, with significantly higher levels of support among younger generations than among older generations. On 20 September 2011, gay and lesbian citizens were allowed to serve in the United States military. For the first time, on 17 June 2011, the United Nations passes a motion in support of [[GLBT rights]] across the world.
The aging of populations in the [[developed countries]], most prominently [[European Union|Europe]] and Japan, continues as the [[Baby boomers]] generation reaches the age of retirement. This has caused a large debate over the Medicare and Social Security programs in the United States. Many popular opinions among Americans are that either the retirement age should be raised,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20009192-503544.html |title=John Boehner: Raise Social Security Retirement Age to 70 â Political Hotsheet |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bragdon |first=Tarren |url=http://www.heritage.org/research/reports/2010/11/time-to-raise-social-securitys-retirement-age |title=Time to Raise Social Securityâs Retirement Age |publisher=Heritage.org |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sahadi |first=Jeanne |url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/08/02/news/economy/social_security_retirement/index.htm |title=Ruckus over raising the Social Security retirement age â Aug. 2, 2010 |publisher=CNN |date=2 August 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=O'Brien |first=Michael |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/106135-boehner-raise-social-securitys-retirement-age-to-70 |title=Top Republican: Raise Social Security's retirement age to 70 â The Hill's Blog Briefing Room |publisher=Thehill.com |date=29 June 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> the Social Security and Medicare programs be replaced with another type of pension,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investors.com/NewsAndAnalysis/Article/586464/201109291833/Cains-Chilean-Model.htm |title=Cain's 'Chilean Model' â Latest Headlines |publisher=Investors.com |date=29 September 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>http://www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/ssb/v59n3/v59n3p45.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Celia Bigelow |url=http://www.freedomworks.org/blog/cbigelow/chilean-model-of-social-security |title=Chilean Model of Social Security |publisher=FreedomWorks |date=3 October 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> or that the Medicare and Social Security should be abolished in its entirety.<ref>http://www.fee.org/pdf/the-freeman/0905RMEcolumn.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.issues2000.org/2012/Ron_Paul_Social_Security.htm |title=Ron Paul on Social Security |publisher=Issues2000.org |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freecolorado.com/2004/12/qass.html |title=What's Wrong with Social Security and How to Abolish It |publisher=Freecolorado.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
The world's major civilizations are now interacting more than ever in history, creating tensions but also bringing new ideas to cultures that previously did not have them. This is radically changing the economic and social fabric in virtually every part of the world. China, considered an emerging power in the 1990's and 2000's, has increasingly been called a superpower in the early 2010's, such as at the 2011 meeting between [[Hu Jintao]] and [[Barack Obama]].<ref>http://uk.news.yahoo.com/5/20110119/twl-superpower-talks-china-faces-tough-u-3fd0ae9.html</ref>
[[Individuality]] continues to be in fashion, but not as strong as it was in the 1990's and 2000's. {{citation needed|date=November 2011}} A well noted example of this are [[baby names]], which have become far more individualized since the 1960's, but especially since the 1990's and the introduction of the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/culture/baby-names-uniquness-meaning-information-101130.html|title=Baby Names Reveal More About Parents Than Ever Before|date=30 November 2010|accessdate=1 January 2011|first=Clara|last=Moskowitz|work=[[LiveScience]]}}</ref>
Long distance relocation declines in the United States, reaching their lowest levels since information began being kept in 1948.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110111/ap_on_re_us/us_census_staying_put|title=Census: Long-distance moves in US hit record low|author=Hope Yen|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref>
Youth culture such as [[skateboarding]] continues to spread to countries such as [[Afghanistan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grindtv.com/skate/blog/23666/skateboarding+school+helps+to+empower+kids+in+afghanistan|title=Skateboarding school helps to empower kids in Afghanistan|author=Pete Thomas|publisher=GrindTV}}</ref>
AIDS, a [[pandemic]] in the 1980's, 1990's, and 2000's responsible for killing over 30 million people, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, becomes a treatable condition; though only one case has been [[cure]]d,<ref name="foxnews.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/health/2011/06/02/30-years-later-end-to-aids/ | work=Fox News | title=30 Years Later: An End to AIDS? | date=2 June 2011}}</ref> the disease is no longer a death sentence and with good treatment victims can generally expect to live normal lives and lifespans.<ref name="foxnews.com"/>
Breakfast habits change: among Americans, cereal, a profitable breakfast food throughout the 20th century, declines by the early 1990's and is not nearly as popular by the 2010's.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finance.yahoo.com/family-home/article/112856/breakfast-cereals-declining-popularity-247 |title=breakfast-cereals-declining-popularity-247: Personal Finance News from Yahoo! Finance |publisher=Finance.yahoo.com |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> [[Fast casual]] restaurants such as [[Five Guys]] and [[Chipotle]] also see an uptick in popularity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finance.yahoo.com/family-home/article/112889/five-guys-eating-burgers-street |title=five-guys-eating-burgers-street: Personal Finance News from Yahoo! Finance |publisher=Finance.yahoo.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
In America, migration to the [[Sun Belt]], large during the last decades of the 20th century and the [[2000s decade]], declines; migration in general around the US has been in decline since the beginning of the 1980's.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roth |first=Zachary |url=http://news.yahoo.com/blogs/lookout/end-sun-belt-boom-141509930.html |title=The end of the Sun Belt boom? | The Lookout â Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=28 October 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>
== Science and technology == === Science === [[File:Oblique View of Warm Season Flows in Newton Crater.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[NASA]] announced that its [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]] captured [[Seasonal flows on warm Martian slopes|photographic evidence]] of possible liquid water on [[Mars]] on 5 August 2011]] [[File:CERN LHC Tunnel1.jpg|thumb|150px|left|The first collisions of [[CERN]]'s [[Large Hadron Collider]] took place on 31 March 2010.]] * The [[Large Hadron Collider]]'s first high power collisions took place in March 2010. * Scientists announced in May 2010 that they had developed a form of [[synthetic life]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10134341|title='Artificial life' breakthrough announced by scientists|publisher=BBC | date=20 May 2010}}</ref> * [[Solar aircraft]] became increasingly popular during the decade spearheaded by the [[Solar Impulse Project]] and [[QinetiQ Zephyr]] in 2010. * [[NASA]] will launch the [[James Webb Space Telescope]] as early as 2014 and replace the [[Hubble Space Telescope]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/home/hqnews/2010/jan/HQ_01-001_Grunsfeld.html |title=NASA Astronaut John Grunsfeld, Instrumental to Hubble Telescope Repair, Will Help Oversee its Science Operations |accessdate=2010-01-05 |last=Trinidad |first=Katherine |coauthors=Nicole Cloutier-Lemasters , Cheryl Gundy, Ray Villard |date=2010-01-01 |work=NASA }}</ref> * NASA's [[New Horizons]] probe will reach [[Pluto]] in 2015, completing its main mission, and continuing into the [[Kuiper Belt]]. * Both the [[International Linear Collider]] and [[ITER]] may be completed during the latter half of the decade. * The [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] is scheduled to appear in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/ |title=IPCC website |publisher=Ipcc.ch |accessdate=2010-06-21}}</ref> * On 5 August 2011 [[NASA]] announced that its [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]] captured [[Seasonal flows on warm Martian slopes|photographic evidence]] of possible liquid water on Mars during warm seasons. * Scientists at [[CERN]] declared they have detected neutrinos travelling faster than light which defies the known laws of physics. After modifying the neutrino beam to fire for 3 billionths of a second (160 times shorter than the previous firing) they obtained the same results.<ref>{{Cite news|http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-15791236|publisher=BBC |title=Neutrino experiment repeat at Cern finds same result | date=18 November 2011}}</ref>
=== Technology === [[File:IPad-02.jpg|thumb|left|120px|The [[iPad]] becomes the best selling tech gadget in history]] * By February 2011, the [[IPv4]] internet addresses officially run out. An early period of transition to [[IPv6]] continues during 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2011-02/internet-has-run-out-addresses-its-not-cause-panic-yet|title=The Internet Officially Runs Out of Addresses Today, But It's Not Cause for Panic|author=Dan Nosowitz|publisher=Popular Science}}</ref> * [[Supercomputer]]s are projected to reach [[FLOPS|exaflop scale]] in 2019.<ref>{{cite news |first=Patrick |last=Thibodeau |title=IBM breaks petaflop barrier |url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/08/06/10/IBM_breaks_petaflop_barrier_1.html |work=InfoWorld |date=2008-06-10 }}</ref> * By March 2011, more than 2 billion people used the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|author=By website optimization on 29 Mar 2011 AM |url=http://www.websiteoptimization.com/bw/1103/ |title=Over 2 Billion Internet Users Worldwide â Wireless Broadband 30% Slower than Wired â March 2011 Bandwidth Report |publisher=Websiteoptimization.com |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> * One billion mobile broadband users predicted by sometime in 2011, and 4.6 billion people worldwide were subscribed to mobile phones.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mobiledia.com/news/79588.html|title=Mobile Broadband Users to Top One Billion Mark in 2011|author=Florence Labedays|publisher=Mobiledia}}</ref> * On 27 January 2010, [[Apple Inc.]] launches its first [[tablet computer]] called the [[iPad]] which offers multi-touch interaction with multimedia formats including newspapers, magazines, ebooks, textbooks, photos, movies, TV shows videos, music, word processing documents, spreadsheets, video games. The iPad soon became an immediate bestseller and only months after its release became the best selling tech gadget in history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/storage/portable/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=227700347|title=iPad Is Top Selling Tech Gadget Ever|author=Paul McDougall|publisher=InformationWeek}}</ref> Multiple competing tablet computers are now on the market. * Mobile phone [[Application software|apps]], introduced in the later 2000s, explode in popularity; In June 2011, Americans spent more time using apps than using the [[World Wide Web]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Newark |first=Charles |url=http://blog.flurry.com/bid/63907/Mobile-Apps-Put-the-Web-in-Their-Rear-view-Mirror |title=Mobile Apps Put the Web in Their Rear-view Mirror |publisher=Blog.flurry.com |date=20 June 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> * After a very slow start in the [[1990s]] and [[2000s]], [[ebooks]] outsell print books for the first time in the year [[2011]]. <ref>http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-19/tech/kindle.outsells.books_1_kindle-e-reader-kindle-device-e-books?_s=PM:TECH</ref>
{{-}}
==Additional notable world-wide events== * A [[2010 eruption of EyjafjallajÃ¶kull|series of major volcanic events occur at EyjafjallajÃ¶kull in Iceland]] in April 2010. The eruptions led to widespread [[Air travel disruption after the 2010 EyjafjallajÃ¶kull eruption|disruption of air travel across Europe]] grounding planes and affecting the travel plans of millions of passengers worldwide. This caused a knock-on effect to many events around the world. Scientists began recording volcanic activity there in 2009 which increased through March 2010 culminating in the second phase eruption in April 2010. It is considered the largest air traffic shut-down since World War II.<ref name=SMH2>{{Cite news | title= Qantas cancels flights for a third day |work=The Sydney Morning Herald| date= 18 April 2010 | url= http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-news/qantas-cancels-flights-for-a-third-day-20100418-slv5.html| accessdate= 18 April 2010}}</ref> The [[International Air Transport Association]] (IATA) estimated that the airline industry worldwide would lose {{â¬|148 million}} or {{GBP|130 million}} a day during the disruption.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Wearden, Graeme |title= Ash cloud costing airlines Â£130m a day |url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2010/apr/16/iceland-volcano-airline-industry-iata |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 16 April 2010 |accessdate= 17 April 2010 }}</ref> * 13 October 2010 â [[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident]]: Thirty-three miners near [[CopiapÃ³]], Chile, trapped 700 metres (2,300 ft) underground in a [[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident|mining accident]] in [[San JosÃ© Mine]], are brought back to the surface after surviving for a record 69 days.<ref name="MSNBC">{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39625809/ns/world_news-americas/|title=All 33 Chile miners freed in flawless rescue|date=13 October 2010|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|accessdate=14 October 2010|location=Chile}}</ref> * 29 April 2011 â A television audience of an estimated two billion people<ref>{{cite news |last=Grimley |first=Naomi |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-13245069 |title=Royal wedding: The world watches William and Kate |publisher=BBC News |date=29 April 2011 |accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> watch the [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|wedding]] of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]] and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] at [[Westminster Abbey]] in London.
<gallery widths="180px" heights="120px"> File:Eruption of EyjafjallajÃ¶kull Volcano, Iceland April 17 Detail.jpg|The ash plume from the volcano beneath the [[EyjafjallajÃ¶kull]] ice cap, over the North Atlantic as seen from space by [[NASA]]'s [[Aqua (satellite)|Aqua]] satellite on 17 April 2010 File:Mina San JosÃ© - Mario GÃ³mez Rescue - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|[[2010 CopiapÃ³ mining accident]] File:All smiles Wedding of Prince William of Wales and Kate Middleton.jpg|[[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]] </gallery>
== Popular culture == ===Film=== {{Main|2010s in film}} * Oscar winners: ''[[The King's Speech]]'' (2010)
On 31 January 2010, ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' became the first film to cross the $2 billion mark in the worldwide box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=9711561|title='Avatar' Wins Box Office, Nears Domestic Record|accessdate=2 February 2010|publisher=ABC News}}</ref> It is also one of the first in a trend towards high quality [[3-D film|3D]] movies.
In 2010, [[Kathryn Bigelow]] became the first woman to receive the [[Academy Award for Best Director]] for the 2009 movie ''[[The Hurt Locker]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/2010/03/08/2010-03-08_the_hurt_locker_is_lowestgrossing_movie_to_ever_win_best_picture_may_get_postosc.html |title='The Hurt Locker' is lowest-grossing movie to ever win Best Picture, but it may get post-Oscar bump |work=NY Daily News |author=Carter, Nicole |date=8 March 2010 |accessdate=2010-04-06 |location=New York}}</ref>
In 2010, ''[[Toy Story 3]]'' became the first animated film to gross more than $1 billion worldwide.<ref name="mojo">{{cite web | url = http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2904&p=.htm | title = 'Toy Story 3' Reaches $1 Billion | publisher = [[Amazon.com]] | work = [[Box Office Mojo]] | date = 29 July 2010 | accessdate = 21 August 2010 }}</ref>
===Music=== <!--Avoid favoritism by not mentioning specific artists; keep that to the main '2010s in music' article. Keep in mind that this subsection is merely a summary and not an advertising device or place to list your favorite groups or artists. This is mostly for long-term, observed trends and styles.--> {{Main|2010s in music}}
The early 2010s have musically been dominated by a variety of styles and artists. Globalization and the internet have erased political borders providing musicians to have their material to be heard all over the globe. The shrinking of the music industry due to the internet has also [[localized]] music, as there are fewer artists who become big enough to be internationally famous. Musical paradigm shifts in the [[2000s in music|previous decade]] regarding how people obtain and listen to music including the rise of the [[MP3|MP3 format]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Grandoni |first=Dino |url=http://news.yahoo.com/ipod-die-210520713.html |title=The iPod Is About to Die â Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref>,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reviews.cnet.com/4520-6450_7-6266276-1.html |title=MP3 Insider: Top five ways MP3 has changed the world â CNET Reviews |publisher=Reviews.cnet.com |date=20 July 2005 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> [[Pop Idol|televised national musical contests]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buzzle.com/articles/music-and-reality-tv.html |title=Music and Reality TV |publisher=Buzzle.com |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> and the declining influence of the [[2000s in the music industry|recording industry]] have had major effects on the state of music globally in a relatively short time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/02/02/news/companies/napster_music_industry|title=Music's lost decade: Sales cut in half|author=David Goldman|publisher=CNN|date=2 February 2010}}</ref> According to Nielson Soundscan, by 2009 CDs accounted for 79 percent of album sales, with 20 percent coming from digital, representing both a 10 percent drop and gain for both formats in 2 years.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/Music/07/19/cd.digital.sales/index.html| work=CNN | title=Is the death of the CD looming? | date=2010-07-20 | accessdate=3 November 2011 | first1=Lisa | last1=France}}</ref>
In terms of [[popular music]], the heavy use of [[Auto-Tune]] has dramatically changed the landscape of the Top-40 charts. At the same time, [[electronic dance music]] and [[electropop]] have gained significant popularity; electronic in general became widespread in the early-2010s mixing elements of [[Chiptune]], [[Second Wave synthpop]] mixed with rap and other various [[electronic music]], into a sound that differentiates 2010s music from the popular music styles of the early 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.digitalphotocity.com/2281/producing-electronic-music-in-2010-is-the-digital-revolution |title=Producing Electronic Music In 2010 Is The Digital Revolution |publisher=Digitalphotocity.com |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dfdubreport.com/2010/12/09/why-electronic-music-rules/ |title=Blog Archive Â» Why Electronic Music Rules |publisher=dfDubReport |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> In the United Kingdom, [[Dubstep]] is rising in popularity,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starobserver.com.au/play/reviews-play/2010/12/16/dubstep-invasion-kid-kenobi-glovecats/40226 |title=Dubstep Invasion â Kid Kenobi & Glovecats | Star Online |publisher=Starobserver.com.au |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> which is a style that mirrors the electronic-leaning musical trends elsewhere.
=== Architecture === [[File:Burj Khalifa 005.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The [[Burj Khalifa]] became the world's tallest building when completed in 2010.]] * [[Burj Khalifa]] becomes the [[List of tallest buildings and structures in the world|tallest man-made structure]] ever built, standing at 828 m (2,717 ft), after it officially opened on 4 January 2010. * [[One World Trade Center]], an environmentally integrated structure<ref name = "Manhattan">Lower Manhattan Construction Command Center (2010). [http://www.lowermanhattan.info/construction/project_updates/freedom_tower_26204.aspx ''1 World Trade Center (Freedom Tower)'']. Retrieved 22 March 2010.</ref> which is set to become the tallest building in the United States, is expected to open in April 2013.<ref name="panynj-ward2">{{cite report |title=World Trade Center Report: A Roadmap Forward |last=Ward |first=Chris |year=2008 |publisher=Port Authority of New York and New Jersey |pages=26 |url=http://www.panynj.gov/pdf/WTC_Presentation_Oct08.pdf |accessdate=2 October 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref> By December 2010, it had reached half of its designed height. * China's [[Three Gorges Dam]] is scheduled to be fully operational in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/english/2006-05/19/content_285414.htm |title=Three Gorges to become center for China power grid in 2011: official |publisher=Gov.cn |date=19 May 2006 |accessdate=10 November 2011}}</ref> * The [[Gotthard Base Tunnel]], the [[List of tunnels by length|world's longest railway tunnel]], is scheduled to be completed in 2017 or 2018.
